Beaver Damned
The decision of the Junior Class to cancel the forthcoming picnic at Beaver Dam in response to the racially
prejudiced sentiments expressed by the Beaver Dam
ownership is inadequate. The principle invoked, that the
class need not contribute to the welfare of racists, is certainly laudable. The letter of protest being sent to the
Beaver Dam owners will no doubt be forceful, forthright
and righteous to the utmost degree.
This approach of the Junior Class has two unfortunate
results, however. First, there is no picnic. Second, the
cause of a reasonable free society is advanced not one jot.
And what, in effect, is happening here is that the ownership of Beaver Dam and others of their ilk can only be
encouraged by the aquiescence of the Junior Class.
Far more effective a protest would have been a decision to hold the picnic in any case. Such a decision
011111 accomplish two results. First, the picnic
would be
held. Second, and most important, such a decision on
the part of the Junior Class would place the Beaver Dam
bigots in a put up or shut up position.
The picnic should he held, anti it would then be incumbent upon the Beaver Dam owners to create an incident out of which a legitimate issue could he drawn. If
they did create such an incident, then a far more potent
protest than letter writing could be instigated.
What is comes down to is this: Is the Junior Class
willing to stick its neck out for the principle of basic
justice and essential civil rights? Apparently it is not;
and this is lamentable.

Course Guide
The 1966 Course Guide put out by the Student
Council this past week is a more than adequate first
effort. Most of the evaluations reflected a successful attempt to convey essential information about courses from
the student's point of view.
Special emphasis was given to evaluations of professors, and the editors, on the whole, handled this matter
tactfully. The Guide would have been of little use had
it thoughtlessly deprecated the efforts of some faculty
members, or had it gone to the other extreme and omitted the subject entirely. Instructive as the comments are
to the.students, they should he more so to the professors
and instructors who received poor ratings.
Although the Guide covers the evaluative aspects
of the courses quite well, it assumes that its readers are
well acquainted with the subject matter of the course
being offered. This assumption is erroneous, anti inasas the Hopkins Catalogue fails to go into any detail in
in this area, the Course Guide definitely is needed to fill
the gap. One method would be to engage the aid of upperclasm majors and concentrates, who could outline in
more detail what Material is being covered in the courses
given in their departments, supplying critical remarks as
well. This would entail a good deal of research, but would
greatly enhance the comprehensiveness of the Guide,

Editor's Notes The following special

Wilson is a senior and political science

Author's Note: With the permission of
the editors of the News-Letter, it was
decided to limit this special report to
the work being done on the behavior of
the driver. Every aspect of highway
safety is so complex that even that part
had to be treated superficially in this
limited space. The role of the automobile
and the roadway could not possibly be
included.
The automobile has celebrated the
classic three-score-years-and-ten on the
American scene. In those few short generations it has become one of the most
thoroughly democratized parts of our
national, every-day life; perhaps even an
institution. It has come to mean to the
people who use it many things more
than just simply a vehicle, or transportation. Its romance has blossomed beyond any rational level. It has drasticly affected the face of the land and the
habits of our people. It has also affected
the manner and timeliness of their demise. Its impact exceeds that of the
Colt repeater on these shores during the
last century, or that of the sailing ship
during the Renaissance in Europe.
Its start was an inauspicious and undisciplined one. Its growth served only
to compound its lack of discipline. In
1900 there were but 8,000 automobiles
on our roads, unquestionably the worst
in the Western World. By 1910 pressure
was growing to improve the roads, and
the Congress authorized the President
to appoint a commission to study the
problem. Auto registration had already
reached 458,377.
In 1900 auto production was only 4,192
units, but by 1910, it was 181,000. An
important and peculiarly American thing
had happened in the interim: Henry
Ford had introduced the Model T. R. L.
Bruckberger says that for us, Ford's
quiet revolution will overshadow Lenin's
violent one. Aldous Huxley's "Brave
New World" certainly projects this
thesis to the extreme, where Ford is
treated as the Diety.
John B. Rae, in his scolarly history
of the American automobile in the
Chicago University History of American
Civilization series says "the fast growing
United States offered conditions in
which it was profitable to employ techniques that achieved quantity production with a minimum of labor, particularly if the high cost of skilled craftsmen could be dispensed with, and there
were no strong vested interests to resist
innovation." As early as 1850, this technique had been called "the American
system of manufacture."

The automobile presented the "system" its greatest challenge yet. Until
then, the "system" had been able to roll
along easily producing pins and firearms, whiskey and furniture. The automobile was the first complex, popular
device to which the "system" could be
applied. And the complexity of the device made the commitment of the enterprises necessarily greater, the obstacles
more numerous, and the need for
volume production unavoidable. In the
final application, it was early realized
that volume would have not only to
remain high, but to continually grow.
This meant, eventually, that autos would
have to be put in the hands of the
young and the old, the rich and the poor,
the pillars of society and the delinquent,
the healthy and the sick.
The Model T was different from every
earlier "cheap" cars. Ford decided to
build a car that would first satisfy the
farmer and the country doctor; then he
worked at cost reduction. Later, in every
OA. auto-producing country in the world,

the mass-car producers followed suit.
Andre Citroen told designers to come
up with a car that could carry a dozen
eggs over unpaved roads without breakage, and that is how the Deux Cheveaux
was tested. One of the characteristics of
any such car, naturally, is that you need
not have much skill to drive one, And
the purchaser is rarely asked by an auto
dealer to demonstrate his ability to control moving vehicles in general.
After World War I there were 8,131,522
cars on our highways, and by 1950 the
number had risen to 49,161,691. Today
there are approximately 89,000,000. And
the cars that have been sold have been

operated at ever-increasing speeds by the
same kind of people who bought the
first Model T. While in the period from
1949 to 1949 the average speed on American highways increased by only four
miles an hour, the proportion of drivers
going faster than 50 miles an hour had
risen from 39 per cent to 56 per cent
of the total. In 1959, about 15 per cent
of all drivers exceeded 60 miles an hour.
What does this proliferation of motor
vehicles mean for Americans? It means
that when you stand on a street corner
and watch the cars go by, one in every
two cars will be junked because of an
auto accident. It means that one in
every ten will kill, or have someone
killed in it. It means that one in every
four children born this year will be
killed or maimed permanently in an
auto accident. It means that every single
family in the United States will lose at
least one member in a traffic accident
before 1975.
If you are between five and thirty
years old it means that your chances of
being killed in an auto accident are
greater than due to any other cause;
and since all Americans are computed
into these figures, "any other cause" includes Viet Cong ambush. Further, it
means that three cents out of every dollar you spend for anything goes to pay
the direct costs of traffic accidents—
from replacing a fender to buying the
burial plot. Work loss and reduced production are not included in that.
There can be no doubt that during
the next century Americans will wonder
how we allowed the auto death toll to
continue so high and so long. Just as we
look back with shame on sweatshops
and strike-breakers, they will look back
with horror on the casualty list that
now tops 1,500,000 during the history of
the automobile on these shores. In 1959,
the Secretary of Commerce predicted
that 51,000 would not die annually in
traffic accidents before 1975. Now, for
1966, estimates range from 51,000 to
65,000—nine years earlier than was
thought possible just seven years ago.
The 1966 Pontiac Tempest has been
described as "an orgasm on wheels." In
Detroit, it is a truism that "styling cars
sells cars, and safey does not." In 1956,
William Mitchell of General Motors said
safe cars appeal only to "squares," "and
there ain't any squares no more." In
"The Insolent Chariots", John Keats runs
down the list of the then-best-sellers and
finds breasts and buttocks on each of
them. Evidentally, it is sex in styling
that sells oars, for the 1966 Pontiac

Tempest is the third selling car, yet is
far from the third lowest priced.
The realization that this was being
done consciously by the auto makers
has developed, in recent months, into a
concentrated attack on auto design as a
factor in auto accidents. Criticism has
been made of the emphasis on speed in
auto advertising. The autoindustry has
replied by saying that they operate in
one of the last fre market in America,
and in a fre market, the fact that they
are here to answer the criticism proves
that their approach has been the correct
and democratic one. The Detroit auto
makers are the last survivors of a
dying species—the social Darwinists.
Their critics have their valid points and
the auto makers have their valid points.
too. Were cars changed so completely
that safety were always the prime consideration, the human animal being what
he is, he would still tend to favor the
company that produced a car with sex
appeal, and relative safety would have
little selling power. The final and only
potentially successful approach, then, to
reducing accidents, is a complete understanding of the behavior and ability
of the driver, and an intelligent and just
application of the understanding that is
obtained.
There are two things which exist in
our system which have traditionally
tended to inhibit the undertaking of
such an effort. One is "the Problem of
the Voter-Driver." The other is the inherent research gap. Both problems can
be solved, but to solve either will require a virtual overturning of practices
and sentiment in the State legislatures
and the Congress. At which level the
need is greatest is outside the scope of
this special report. Suffice it to say, the
need exists.
The overturning has started. During
the past twelve months more state-level
highway safety proposals have been considered than in the preceding threescore-years-and-ten the automobile has
been with us. The cost of those enacted
alone is staggering, when the Federal
programs are included, and the final
shame is that the deaths on our highways will continue to grow, or at least,
not fall by very much, despite these efforts, until the problem if the antisocial, and extra-social, driver is tackled.

The Problem of
Voter-Driver
"The Problem of the Voter-Driver" can
be easily stated. Although most drivers
do not vote, they could; and most voters
do drive. Most drivers would vote, it
is felt, if they thought their "right" to
drive threatened. The "Problem of the
Voter-Driver" caused near-panic in the
Maryland legislature during the last session, and the legislator's fear of the
mythological problem defeated (since
logic could not) the State's first proposal so-called "implied consent" law.
One governor has been courageous
enough to tackle the fears of the problem head-on. North Carolina's Dan
Moore took a tough line in a special
address to the State's General Assembly
saying "We must not, we cannot, let
individual inconvenience block our determination. Neither you nor I can afford to let our political ambition stand
in the way. Our obligation to the men,
women, and children of North Carolina,
demands that we take firm action now,"
Governor Moore backed his words
pith actions that put the Maryland administration to shame. An inspection
law, doubled driver education appropriations, increased highway patrolmen
authoritizations, centralized highway
safety authorities and accident research
programs, traffic court reforms, and
several technical laws governing vehicle
equipment were enacted. Dan Moore is
not the first Governor to tackle the
problem but he will probably be recorded as the first effective one in a
great renewed untertaking. And he will
probably be able to report that the

The decision of the Junior Class to cancel the forthcoming picnic at Beaver Dam in response to the racially
prejudiced sentiments expressed by the Beaver Dam
ownership is inadequate. The principle invoked, that the
class need not contribute to the welfare of racists, is certainly laudable. The letter of protest being sent to the
Beaver Dam owners will no doubt be forceful, forthright
and righteous to the utmost degree.
This approach of the Junior Class has two unfortunate
results, however. First, there is no picnic. Second, the
cause of a reasonable free society is advanced not one jot.
And what, in effect, is happening here is that the ownership of Beaver Dam and others of their ilk can only be
encouraged by the aquiescence of the Junior Class.

willing to stick its neck out for the principle of basic
justice and essential civil rights? Apparently it is not;
and this is lamentable.

Editor's Notes The following special
News-Letter supplement is a concise and
inclusive treatment of a subject very
much in the news today. It deals with a
very serious problem in our society.
Wilson is a senior and political science
major at Johns Hopkins.
Author's Note: With the permission of
the editors of the News-Letter, it was
decided to limit this special report to
the work being done on the behavior of
the driver. Every aspect of highway
safety is so complex that even that part
had to be treated superficially in this
limited space. The role of the automobile
and the roadway could not possibly be
included.
The automobile has celebrated the
classic three-score-years-and-ten on the
American scene. In those few short generations it has become one of the most
thoroughly democratized parts of our
national, every-day life; perhaps even an
institution. It has come to mean to the
people who use it many things more
than just simply a vehicle, or transportation. Its romance has blossomed beyond any rational level. It has drasticly affected the face of the land and the
habits of our people. It has also affected
the manner and timeliness of their demise. Its impact exceeds that of the
Colt repeater on these shores during the
last century, or that of the sailing ship
during the Renaissance in Europe.
Its start was an inauspicious and undisciplined one. Its growth served only
to compound its lack of discipline. In
1900 there were but 8,000 automobiles
on our roads, unquestionably the worst
in the Western World. By 1910 pressure
was growing to improve the roads, and
the Congress authorized the President
to appoint a commission to study the
